Posts.Content: Hello again Lee, I can’t count on the healing time of my first mastectomy, as I had the misfortune of an internal stitch causing an infection.  I had my second mastectomy on Wed 14 March.  Was home on Fri 16th.  I have three drains, which, knowing the way, opt to empty, measure the fluid and logging down myself. Thus, freeing up a home visitor and allowing them to attend the more needy.  My waste count is rapidly decreasing each day - so I’m hoping that at tomorrow’s clinic my drains may be removed.   As I opted for Becker Implants, when the area has settled, saline fill via a port is my way.  To have your mastectomy, you may still be required to have radiotherapy.  To solely have radiotherapy, is not (FOR ME) belt ‘n’ braces.  It’s a choice only you can make with your consultant BUT it is YOUR choice.  I thank you for your good wishes. This time around, it’s a breeze. I am getting grief via the coiled pipes. I am avidly looking for any sign of red - as an alert for wrong going.  So far, so good.  Back to you...

Posts.Content: Hello Lee, I am quite sad that you feel as though you are “swept along” for it’s your choice too.  I became well read via U.K. breast cancer sites and am thankful for an excellent team at Frimley Park Hospital. I have been knowledgeable of procedure and vocal in choice. I wanted all tissue gone. End of. I am finally home today from my second (elective) mastectomy. Statistics can be a wonderful thing - on paper. I wanted to have done my utmost, for sound mind   Judgment, will tell at a later date. Know your body. Know your choices. Good luck.
